figgy.title: Monogram images not loading in viewer
Numismatic Monograms should preserve their images

comments.body: Monograms are preserving their binaries. We we're looking at the PreservationObject of the Monogram instead of the FileSet. I checked a few on the Figgy prod terminal, and they are there.

We found the deleted resource id in the deletion marker search ui. We used `query_service.custom_queries.find_by_property(property: :numismatic_monogram_ids, value: Valkyrie::ID.new(that_id)` to see whether the links were still in place, and they were. We restored the monograph using its deletion marker in the ui.

We discovered and created https://github.com/pulibrary/figgy/issues/5784 but in this case the user confirmed that there had not been an image.

comments.body: Welcome controller: https://github.com/pulibrary/pdc_describe/blob/main/app/controllers/welcome_controller.rb
https://github.com/pulibrary/pdc_describe/commit/f9120c03c139becb7bba3fdcf257e1465bea7008

The above-described AJAX issue appears to be inconsistently occurring across browsers, and is not the root cause of the issue of not being able to see submissions in a published issue. While upgrading to OJS 3.3.0-14 simplifies the workflow, this issue is resolvable within the current UI. Issues 16, 17, 18, and 19 were fixed (and confirmed as fixed with Yuan and Hannah over Slack) through the following method. Each submission that is linked to a published issue must be published in production. Submissions can be unpublished after an issue has been published, and would therefore disappear from the public UI. If submissions are not appearing in a published issue, this can be fixed as follows: ## Step 1 Go to the "Submissions" section and locate the submission that is not displaying. These are searchable under "All Active" or "Archives," depending on the state of the submission. If the submission's state is anything other than "Published," it will not display publicly in the issue table of contents. ## Step 2 Once you have located the submission, click the "View" button. ## Step 3 From the "Workflow > Production" tab, click on the "Schedule for Publication" button. ## Step 4 You will be forwarded to the "Workflow > Publication" tab for the submission. Click the "Schedule for Publication" button here as well. ## Step 5 If everything is correctly set within the submission, you will receive a confirmation dialog box like the following: Click "Publish" to complete publishing the submission. ## Step 6 Once a submission is published, you will see the red band warning that the submission is published and cannot be edited: If you need to edit a submission that has been published, you will need to unpublish it first, then re-publish it when you are done. ## Step 7 To validate that your submission should be visible in the public UI, you can look it up in the "Submissions > Archives" section. If your submission is present in the search results and has the solid green "Published" label as shown below, your submission should be correctly configured to display in the public UI:
I will share the above tutorial with Hannah and Yuan.  Any additional actions needed should be taken on a new ticket.

pdc_describe.title: PDC Describe Production set and ready for data migration

comments.body: Update: Others in PRDS are experiencing this same error message.

The error happens when editing any published record. The logs show a problem with a missing column in the `upload_snapshots` table:

```
F, [2023-05-03T14:00:54.961517 #710907] FATAL -- : [5f01e5db-6165-422e-b331-18ef6fdd8077]   
[5f01e5db-6165-422e-b331-18ef6fdd8077] ActiveRecord::StatementInvalid (PG::UndefinedColumn: ERROR:  column upload_snapshots.url does not exist
LINE 1: ...hots" WHERE "upload_snapshots"."work_id" = $1 AND "upload_sn...
                                                             ^
HINT:  Perhaps you meant to reference the column "upload_snapshots.uri".
):
[5f01e5db-6165-422e-b331-18ef6fdd8077]   
[5f01e5db-6165-422e-b331-18ef6fdd8077] app/models/work.rb:480:in `block in new_s3_files'
[5f01e5db-6165-422e-b331-18ef6fdd8077] app/models/work.rb:479:in `reject'
[5f01e5db-6165-422e-b331-18ef6fdd8077] app/models/work.rb:479:in `new_s3_files'
[5f01e5db-6165-422e-b331-18ef6fdd8077] app/models/work.rb:485:in `new_snapshots'
[5f01e5db-6165-422e-b331-18ef6fdd8077] app/models/work.rb:491:in `current_snapshots'
[5f01e5db-6165-422e-b331-18ef6fdd8077] app/models/work.rb:495:in `invalid_snapshots'
[5f01e5db-6165-422e-b331-18ef6fdd8077] app/models/work.rb:528:in `reload_snapshots'
[5f01e5db-6165-422e-b331-18ef6fdd8077] app/controllers/works_controller.rb:69:in `show'
```

@carolyncole and I ran into this issue in our local environments and we had to re-create the database to get around it, but I don't think we want to do this in our staging/production server.

@hectorcorrea https://github.com/pulibrary/pdc_describe/pull/1113 I tested this locally.

Unfortunately we merged a PR that modified the database create. 😢 I think that might have been me...

Table in staging:

```
pdc_describe_staging=> \d upload_snapshots
                                          Table "public.upload_snapshots"
   Column   |              Type              | Collation | Nullable |                   Default                    
------------+--------------------------------+-----------+----------+----------------------------------------------
 id         | bigint                         |           | not null | nextval('upload_snapshots_id_seq'::regclass)
 uri        | character varying              |           | not null | 
 work_id    | bigint                         |           | not null | 
 created_at | timestamp(6) without time zone |           | not null | 
 updated_at | timestamp(6) without time zone |           | not null | 
Indexes:
    "upload_snapshots_pkey" PRIMARY KEY, btree (id)
    "index_upload_snapshots_on_work_id" btree (work_id)
Foreign-key constraints:
    "fk_rails_0e01bc9fbb" FOREIGN KEY (work_id) REFERENCES works(id)
```

Table as we create it:

```
  create_table "upload_snapshots", force: :cascade do |t|
    t.string "filename"
    t.string "url"
    t.bigint "version"
    t.string "checksum"
    t.bigint "work_id", null: false
    t.datetime "created_at", precision: 6, null: false
    t.datetime "updated_at", precision: 6, null: false
    t.index ["work_id"], name: "index_upload_snapshots_on_work_id"
  end
```

Fixed with PR https://github.com/pulibrary/pdc_describe/pull/1113

Database in staging now has the correct fields:

```
pdc_describe_staging=> \d upload_snapshots
                                          Table "public.upload_snapshots"
   Column   |              Type              | Collation | Nullable |                   Default                    
------------+--------------------------------+-----------+----------+----------------------------------------------
 id         | bigint                         |           | not null | nextval('upload_snapshots_id_seq'::regclass)
 url        | character varying              |           | not null | 
 work_id    | bigint                         |           | not null | 
 created_at | timestamp(6) without time zone |           | not null | 
 updated_at | timestamp(6) without time zone |           | not null | 
 filename   | character varying              |           |          | 
 version    | bigint                         |           |          | 
 checksum   | character varying              |           |          | 
Indexes:
    "upload_snapshots_pkey" PRIMARY KEY, btree (id)
    "index_upload_snapshots_on_work_id" btree (work_id)
Foreign-key constraints:
    "fk_rails_0e01bc9fbb" FOREIGN KEY (work_id) REFERENCES works(id)
```

pdc_describe.title: Ensure that checksums are appropriately configured in S3 for preservation

comments.body: @kelynch The link here is talking about additional checksums.  What kind of additional checksums are you expecting AWS to calculate?  We currently utilize MD5 checksums that are built in, but no additional checksum, nor do we ask AWS to calculate an additional checksum during any processing.

pdc_describe.title: Describe Form: Add Affiliation (and ROR) to the Creator Property Set

comments.body: ![Screenshot 2023-05-03 at 10 11 16 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/65608/235941572-d63bd60f-7423-400b-96e9-203ef7eff0c7.png)

We could hide some of the migration provenance from the user (possibly roll it up) so it looks more like 👆

Can we roll up all migration steps into one (approve, metadata, files).  This could be a separate ticket or part of this one.  How do do this...

Whoever added the metadata and whoever hit the file migration button should be recorded (not necessarily displayed in the UI).  Also a timestamp for each activity.

We will need to produce proof that files that were in DataSpace were migrated intact to PDC Describe if we get audited.  We can use checksums for this.

We should record all activities in the system and be able to tag them as "migration" so they do not show up in the UI.

comments.body: Closing in favor of #3864.
I had a failure when trying to deploy Orangelight using this branch - see https://ansible-tower.princeton.edu/#/jobs/playbook/837/output
The GitHub connection isn't quite ready for prime time yet. It still relies on pulbot and it auto-merges main into branches. Reverting for now in #3865 and closing this enhancement.

comments.body: If possible, rename the GitHub token used in #3867 - currently it's called `pulbot` even though it does not use any code from the pulbot repo. The name `pulbot` currently shows up on deployment updates to GitHub PRs and on notifications from GitHub to slack, which is a little confusing. If we don't change this, document it so we don't forgot how things fit together.
